description: A large tuna species found in pelagic waters of tropical and subtropical oceans worldwide. Known for its speed and strength, it is a popular game fish.

diet: Apex predator; feeds on fish, cephalopods, crustaceans
description: A powerful apex predator in its habitat. Known for its aggressive hunting strategies, sometimes in packs.

habitat: Coral reefs, from 4 to 180 m deep
diet: Mainly fish, some crustaceans and molluscs
description: Also known as the red snapper, it is a common reef fish. Large individuals can cause ciguatera poisoning.
Famous for its large dorsal fin (the 'sail') and being one of the fastest fish in the ocean, reaching speeds over 110 km/h.

habitat: Freshwater lakes and rivers (e.g., Lake Victoria)
diet: Primarily fish, including its own species
description: A large freshwater predator. Its introduction into Lake Victoria had a major, complex impact on the local ecosystem.
A prized game fish known for its high speed and high-quality flesh. It has a long, streamlined body with a distinctive pattern of vertical blue bars.

habitat: Coral reefs, often in caves or near ledges
description: A very large grouper with a curious and friendly disposition towards divers. It has a distinctive pattern of large, dark, potato-like blotches.

habitat: Surface waters of tropical and subtropical oceans
description: Also known as Dorado, this fish is famous for its brilliant colors (gold, blue, green) which fade rapidly after death. It is a very fast-growing species.
A popular aquarium fish known for its vibrant blue body, yellow dorsal fin, and white throat. It can be aggressive towards other tangs.

habitat: Nearshore coral reefs, seagrass beds, and mangroves
description: A formidable ambush predator with a long, snake-like body and a prominent jaw filled with sharp teeth. It relies on surprise attacks to catch its prey.
Identified by the yellow-orange band running through its eye. It often forms schools to feed on algae on the sea floor.

habitat: Coastal waters over reefs and sandy bottoms
description: Juveniles have long, filamentous dorsal and anal fin rays that shorten with age. It is a popular game and food fish.
A hardy fish capable of tolerating a wide range of salinities. It is an important commercial species in many regions.

habitat: Oceanic and coastal waters, from surface to 500m
description: Easily recognized by its extremely long upper caudal fin lobe, which it uses like a whip to stun and kill prey.
A dark-bodied grouper with a strikingly bright orange to red mouth interior, which it displays when threatened.

habitat: Coastal slopes and sandy areas near reefs
description: Features small pale blue spots on its upper body and can rapidly change its color. It uses its strong jaws to crush shells.
Has an elongated body covered in irregular blue lines and black spots. It is a poor swimmer, often drifting with the current.

habitat: Shallow coral reefs and rocky shores
description: A common damselfish with five distinct black vertical bars. They often form large feeding aggregations.
Also known as the Bristle-tooth Tang, it uses its specialized teeth to scrape detritus from reef surfaces. Can cause ciguatera.
A small, silvery fish known for its highly protrusible mouth and the slimy mucus it secretes. It is bioluminescent.
A strong and aggressive predator, recognized by its brilliant electric blue fins and scattered blue and black spots.
The largest living member of the wrasse family, known for the prominent bulge on its forehead. It plays a crucial role in reef health.
One of the most recognizable reef fish due to its unique and vivid coloration, featuring large white spots on its lower body and a yellow 'lipstick' pattern.
Undergoes a dramatic color change from juvenile to adult. Juveniles are dark blue with concentric white rings, while adults have yellow and blue stripes.
Known for its venomous fin rays and dramatic appearance. It's an invasive species in the Atlantic, causing significant ecological damage.
Like other parrotfish, it plays a vital role in bioerosion and the production of coral sand. It exhibits complex social and reproductive behaviors.

habitat: Reef flats and slopes, hiding in crevices
description: A large moray eel with a distinctive pattern of black blotches separated by a white honeycomb-like network.
Juveniles are known for mimicking dead leaves by turning brown and floating on their side. Adults are more disc-shaped and silvery.
Adults develop a long, horn-like rostrum in front of their eyes. They can rapidly change color depending on their mood or environment.
A large and powerful triggerfish known for its territorial behavior, often digging large pits in the sand to search for food.

habitat: Coral-rich areas of lagoons and seaward reefs
description: The largest of the butterflyfishes, it is distinguished by its pattern of thin vertical black lines on a white body.
Possesses an extraordinary ability to protrude its jaws forward to form a tube, which it uses to suck in prey from a distance.

habitat: Shallow inshore waters, including reef flats and lagoons
description: One of the most common sharks found on tropical coral reefs, easily identified by the prominent black tips on its fins, especially the dorsal fin.
A colorful stingray with large, bright blue spots on its oval-shaped disc. It often hides in sandy areas during the day.
A large, powerful predator that, despite its name, is not a true tuna but a close relative. It is named for its large, conical teeth.
Often mistaken for the Moorish Idol, this species is known for its long, white, filamentous dorsal fin. They often live in pairs.
A colorful unicornfish that lacks the prominent rostral horn of other species. It has two bright orange spines on the caudal peduncle for defense.
A widespread and common grouper with a dark body covered in hundreds of small, electric-blue spots. It is a territorial ambush predator.

diet: Nudibranchs, coral polyps, and small invertebrates
description: Named for the black patch around its eye, which resembles the mask of a raccoon. This species is often active at night.

habitat: Weedy areas of lagoons and seaward reefs
description: A striking wrasse with bold black and white vertical stripes and a red-orange patch on its breast. It uses its strong teeth to crush hard-shelled prey.
A beautiful angelfish with a dark blue body covered in a network of bright blue, scribbled lines. The head and tail are bright yellow.

diet: Sea urchins, molluscs, crustaceans, and coral
description: The largest species of triggerfish, known for its aggressive behavior, especially when guarding its nest. It can deliver a painful bite.

habitat: Clear, calm waters of coral reefs
description: An ambush predator with a very long, tubular snout. It often hides by aligning itself vertically with sea whips or other objects to camouflage.

habitat: Coral reefs, often resting in caves or on the sand
description: A slender shark easily identified by the white tips on its dorsal and caudal fins. It is one of the few sharks that can pump water over its gills and lie motionless on the bottom.
A very popular aquarium fish due to its vibrant, uniform yellow color. It possesses a sharp spine at the base of its tail for defense.
Named for its striking pattern of black and white vertical stripes. Unlike other morays, it has molar-like teeth adapted for crushing hard-shelled prey.

habitat: Brackish estuaries and mangroves, sometimes entering freshwater
description: A silvery, diamond-shaped fish with long, pointed dorsal and anal fins, giving it a crescent-like profile. Often found in schools.

diet: Parasites and dead tissue from other fish
description: A small wrasse famous for its symbiotic relationship with larger fish, which it cleans of ectoparasites. It performs a distinctive 'dance' to attract clients.
Juveniles are brown with large white blotches and have an unusual, undulating swimming motion, thought to mimic a toxic flatworm. Adults are greyish with dark spots.

diet: Sponges, tunicates, and other benthic invertebrates
description: The sole species in its family, the Moorish Idol is known for its distinctively compressed, disc-like body and long, sickle-shaped dorsal fin. It is notoriously difficult to keep in aquariums.

habitat: Coastal areas, especially around coral reefs
description: A schooling fish with a distinctive yellow caudal fin and a blue and silver body. They are often seen in large, fast-moving groups.
Named for its large eyes, this species forms large, impressive schools during the day, dispersing at night to hunt.
Juveniles are a brilliant electric blue with a yellow dorsal fin, while adults become a darker, purplish-grey but retain the yellow fins.

habitat: Sandy areas near coral reefs and seagrass beds
description: Characterized by its long, pointed snout. It is a cautious fish, often observed hovering over the sandy bottom.
Has large eyes and a distinctive hump on its nose that develops with age. It uses its powerful molar-like teeth to crush hard-shelled prey.

habitat: Sandy or silty bottoms of lagoons and bays
description: Uses a pair of long chemosensory barbels under its chin to probe the sand for food. It has a large yellow blotch on its side.

habitat: Seagrass beds and sandy areas near reefs
description: Named for the large, dark, thumbprint-like blotch on its side. It is a common and important food fish in many parts of its range.
Also known as the dog-faced puffer, its color is highly variable (grey, yellow, brown) but it always has black spots and blotches. It is highly toxic.
A large, common moray with a yellowish-brown body mottled with dark spots and a distinct yellow-green edge to its fins.
A beautiful fish with bold black and white horizontal stripes and bright yellow fins. They are often found in small groups under ledges.
A very active and common wrasse with a greenish body and six distinct dark vertical bars. It is constantly on the move, searching for food.
Named for the checkerboard-like pattern on its body. It has a yellow spot on its dorsal fin and often buries itself in the sand to sleep or hide.
A brightly colored wrasse with a lunate (crescent-shaped) tail fin. Males are typically more vibrant, with shades of blue, green, and pink.
Named for its very long, bird-like snout, which it uses to probe for prey in reef crevices. Males are dark green-blue, while females are mottled white and brown.
A large, robust grouper with a mottled, brownish pattern that provides excellent camouflage. It is a highly valued food fish.

habitat: Shallow, silty coral reefs and estuaries
description: A smaller grouper with a brownish-grey body covered in small, dark spots. It is often found in less clear, coastal waters.
Distinguished by its large, dark brown blotches and long pectoral fins. It is a well-camouflaged bottom-dweller.

habitat: Coral-rich areas of lagoons and reefs
description: A more elongated grouper with horizontal white stripes and reddish-orange spots. Juveniles are known to mimic wrasses.

habitat: Caves and ledges of coral reefs
description: The largest of the cardinalfishes, it has prominent dark stripes and large, canine-like teeth. It is a nocturnal predator.
A highly territorial surgeonfish with striking blue and yellow horizontal lines. It will aggressively defend its feeding territory from other fish.

habitat: Hard bottoms of lagoons and seaward reefs
description: Named for its pattern of black vertical bars, resembling a prison uniform. They often form large schools to overwhelm territorial damselfishes and feed on their algae.

habitat: Coral-rich areas of lagoons and channels
description: Recognized by two large, dark 'saddles' on its upper body. It is a common and widespread species, often seen in pairs.
Named for the single large, black, teardrop-shaped spot on its side. Its diet consists heavily of coral polyps, making it an obligate corallivore.
A hardy and adaptable butterflyfish with a pattern of chevron-like lines on its body and a broad black band on its tail.
A beautiful species with a pearly-white body and a bright yellow-orange head. It is typically found in pairs.

habitat: Coral reefs, especially areas with Acropora corals
description: A small, bright yellow butterflyfish with a prominent black spot on its side. It is heavily dependent on Acropora corals for food.
A type of bristletooth tang, it has a dark body and is named for the two small black spots at the base of its dorsal and anal fins.
A small surgeonfish with a truncated (squared-off) tail. It has a distinctive yellow ring around its eye.
A small, silvery fish with a highly protrusible mouth that forms a downward-pointing tube. It is bioluminescent.

habitat: Sandy or muddy bottoms in coastal waters
description: Also known as the sicklefish, it has a deep, compressed body and very long pectoral fins. It is an important food fish.
A small, bioluminescent ponyfish found in schools over soft bottoms. It is a common species in its range.
Named for the long, filamentous second spine of its dorsal fin. Like other ponyfishes, it is slimy and bioluminescent.
Distinguished from other ponyfishes by its prominent canine-like teeth. It is an important commercial species.

habitat: Outer reef slopes with strong currents
description: A striking butterflyfish with a broad white band across its dark brown body. It often forms very large schools to feed on plankton in the water column.

habitat: Coral-rich areas of lagoons and reefs
description: Recognizable by the black 'mask' that runs across its eyes and the single black band on its body. Adults develop a small bump on their forehead.
A bright yellow angelfish with a prominent black spot on its forehead and blue lips. The 'three spots' name is somewhat misleading.
A small and beautiful dwarf angelfish with a deep blue body and a bright yellow-orange back and dorsal fin.

habitat: Coral reefs, often in deeper water
description: A colorful dwarf angelfish with a purplish-blue body and vertical orange bars. It is a shy species, often hiding among corals.

diet: Omnivorous; feeds on worms, coral polyps, and algae
description: A hardy butterflyfish with a distinctive black spot on its dorsal fin and a long, whip-like filament extending from the fin.

habitat: Coral reefs, especially with Acropora corals
description: A yellow butterflyfish with a large black spot on its side, which is ringed with blue. It has two blue lines curving down from its eye.
Named for the two prominent black, saddle-like patches (wedges) on its back. It is often seen in pairs.
A pale-bodied butterflyfish covered in small, dark spots, giving it a 'peppered' appearance. It has yellow fins and a black bar on its tail.
A hardy and adaptable butterflyfish with a yellowish-brown body and a broad, dark bar running through its eye.
A beautiful species with a pale body and thin, purplish stripes. It is highly dependent on live coral for food and is threatened by coral bleaching.
Has a striking pattern of curved black lines ('scrawls') on a whitish body. It is an obligate corallivore, feeding only on live coral.
Named for the chevron-like markings on its body. This species is highly territorial and its health is directly linked to the health of Acropora corals.

diet: Small crustaceans, worms, and tube feet of sea urchins
description: Also known as the Longnose Butterflyfish, it uses its extremely long snout like a pair of forceps to extract prey from tiny crevices.
A very slender, surface-dwelling fish with long, beak-like jaws. It is known for leaping out of the water at high speeds.
A small, common coastal trevally that is an important commercial species in many parts of its range.
A graceful ray with a dark dorsal surface covered in white spots or rings. They are powerful swimmers and can leap high out of the water.
